info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 03 at 6:53PM CST by NWS Shreveport
info.description: ...Black Ice will be Possible Across Much of the Region Tonight... Areas of light rain, light freezing rain, sleet, and light snow will gradually diminish from west to east this evening, as much drier air begins to spill east ahead of a strong upper level disturbance that will shift northeast away from the region. While temperatures have fallen below freezing across much of East Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, and Southwest Arkansas, subfreezing temperatures will eventually spread into North Louisiana and portions of Deep East Texas this evening, as the precipitation diminishes. Many roadways, bridges, and overpasses will remain wet as temperatures fall below freezing across North Louisiana and Deep East Texas, with black ice developing over these areas tonight, and persisting across the remainder of the region as well. The black ice is expected to linger through much of the morning Friday, until temperatures are able to climb back above freezing areawide by late morning into the afternoon. Motorists that must drive tonight through Friday morning are urged to slow down and allow for extra travel time during their commute. Be especially cautious when driving over bridges and overpasses, as well as some secondary, less traveled roadways, as these areas will be the most susceptible for black ice formation.
